page.title: Child labour in the diamond industry

revision.text:
'''Child labour in the diamond industry''' is a widely reported and criticized issue on [[diamond industry]] for using [[child labour]] in [[diamond mine]]s and polishing procedures in poor conditions mainly in [[India]] and [[Africa]]. In these mines, children come in contact with minerals, oil and machinery exhaust. In 1997, The [[International Confederation of Free Trade Unions]] claimed that child labour was prospering in the diamond industry in Western India, where the majority of the world's diamonds are cut and polished while workers are often paid only a fraction of 1% of the value of the stones they cut.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/letter_from_america/15377.stm|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120714093557/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/letter_from_america/15377.stm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 July 2012|title=Child Labour Crisis in Diamond Industry|date=26 October 1997|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-09-08}} It is argued that [[economic growth]] in [[Western India]] in the 1980s-90s was associated with an increase in the number of child workers who do simple, repetitive manual tasks that do not require long years of training or experience in low-paying hazardous working conditions that involve drudgery, foreclose the option of school education for most of them. There are organizations and people who try to create a public awareness about the issue, including Janine Roberts, The [[Anti-Slavery Society]], [[Survival International]], IndianNGO, Child Labour News Service (CLNS) managed by the [[Global March Against Child Labor]], and IHS Child Slave Labor News. ==Reports== ===India=== {{Further|Child labour in India#Diamond industry}} In 1997, the [[International Labour Organization]] published a report titled ''Child Labour in the Diamond Industry''{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/public/english/dialogue/actrav/child/proj/childiam.htm|title=Child Labour in the Diamond Industry|publisher=[[International Labour Organization]]|year=1997}} claiming that child labour is highly prevalent in the Indian diamond industry. Child labourers constitute nearly 3% of the total workforce and the percentage of child labourers is as high as 25% in the diamond industry of [[Surat]]. The ICFTU further claimed that child labour was prospering in the diamond industry in western India, where the majority of the world's diamonds are cut and polished. Workers are often paid only a fraction of 1% of the value of the stones they cut.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/letter_from_america/15377.stm|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120714093557/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/letter_from_america/15377.stm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 July 2012|title=Child Labour Crisis in Diamond Industry|date=26 October 1997|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-09-08}} Pravin Nanavati, a Surat-based diamond businessman argued that, since high cost diamonds could easily be lost or broken while cutting or polishing, employing a child labourer would mean risking "[[lakhs]] of [[rupee]]s." Some western countries have called for a [[boycott]] against the diamond industry for establishing a [[monopoly]] in the sector{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}}. Mohan Dhabuwala, secretary of The South Gujarat Diamond Workers Association, argued that while child labour is highly prevalent in the construction and hotel industries, there are few child labourers in the diamond industry of Surat, less than 1% according to their surveys, mainly because of stern punishments and penalties for violation of child labour laws.{{cite web|author=Summit Khanna |location= Ahmedabad |date=2004-12-13 |url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/storypage.php?autono=195628 |title=Diamond industry plays down child labour charges |publisher=Business-standard.com |accessdate=2009-11-09}} In 1998, Madhura Swaminathan from the [[Indira Gandhi Institute of Development Research]] argued that economic growth in western India had been associated with an increase in the number of child workers over the previous 15 years and that children worked at simple repetitive manual tasks in low-paying hazardous jobs, foreclosing the option of school education.{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0305-750X(98)00063-1|title=Economic growth and the persistence of child labour: Evidence from an Indian city|year=1998|last1=Swaminathan|first1=M|journal=World Development|volume=26|page=1513|issue=8}} In 2005, an India-based management consultancy firm, A. F. Ferguson & Co., commissioned a study titled ''Child Labour from the Gem and Jewellery Industry'' "to spread awareness about child labour among the people connected with the industry". They studied 663 manufacturing units at 21 different locations in [[Gujarat]], [[Maharashtra]], [[Rajasthan]], [[West Bengal]] and [[Tamil Nadu]], as an initiative of the [[Gem & Jewelry Export Promotion Council]]. On 12 February, the study was presented at a seminar held by the GJEPC and the Surat Diamond Association, in Surat, India. The report argued that the use of child labour in India’s diamond processing industry has been reduced from 0.55% in 1998 to 0.31% in 2005, "while for the [[synthetic stone]] industry it is estimated to be two-thirds less". GJEPC chairman Bakul Mehta claimed that, "some 500 diamond factory owners took an oath in the city of Palanpur, Gujarat, (home town of leading Gujarati diamond merchants) not to employ children in their factories. Similarly, in Surat, 200 factory owners took the oath," and that GJEPC "remain committed to eradicating child labour from the Indian diamond industry”. He argued that "...the gem and jewelry industry cannot even think of employing children, not only for moral reasons, but that a child could be injured while polishing or cutting the diamonds."{{cite news|url=http://www.diamonds.net/news/NewsItem.aspx?ArticleID=11399|title=Child Labor Practice Drops in India|last=Tanna|first=Ketan|date=14 February 2005|publisher=Rapaport News|accessdate=2009-09-08}}{{cite web|url=http://cities.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=117676|title=Use of child labour in gem industry lower|date=14 February 2005|publisher=[[Indian express]]|accessdate=2009-10-20}}{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/af-ferguson-report-slams-surat-diamond-industry/206061/|title=AF Ferguson report slams Surat diamond industry|last=Khanna|first=Summit |date= 23 February 2005|publisher=[[Business Standard]]|accessdate=2009-10-20}} ===Africa=== On 28 August 2003, [[BBC news]] reported that during the 10-year [[civil war]] in Sierra Leone children were used as combatants and child labourers in the diamond mines of [[Koidu]] in the north-eastern district of Kono. Children aged between 5 and 16 were used in hard labour, for ten hours a day, "digging in soil and [[gravel]], before sifting with a pan for gemstones and shifting heavy mud believed to contain diamonds." In collaboration with [[World Vision]] and [[Aim Sierra Leone]], the Ministry of Gender and Children's Affairs registered 1,200 child miners to get them out of the mines.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3189299.stm|title=Children working in Sierra Leone mines|publisher=BBC news|date=28 August 2003 | first=Lansana | last=Fofana}} On 26 June 2009, [[Human Rights Watch]] published a 62-page report titled ''Diamonds in the Rough. [[Human Rights]] Abuses in the Marange Diamond Fields of Zimbabwe'',[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2009/06/26/diamonds-rough-0 Diamonds in the Rough Human Rights Abuses in the Marange Diamond Fields of Zimbabwe] by [[Human Rights Watch]] 26 June 2009 based on its researchers' "more than 100 one-on-one interviews with witnesses, local miners, police officers, soldiers, local community leaders, victims and relatives, medical staff, human rights lawyers, and activists in [[Harare]], [[Mutare]], and [[Marange]] district in eastern [[Zimbabwe]]", conducted in February 2009. According to the report, "following the discovery of diamonds in Marange in June 2006, the police and army have used brutal force to control access to the diamond fields and to take over unlicensed diamond mining and trading. Some income from the fields has been funnelled to high-level party members of [[ZANU-PF]], which is now part of a power-sharing government that urgently needs revenue as the country faces a dire economic crisis." According to the report, some children work up to eleven hours per day with no pay, and by the estimate of a local lawyer, up to 300 children continue to work for soldiers in the Marange diamond fields.{{cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2009/06/26/diamonds-deadly-toll|title=Diamonds’ Deadly Toll|date=26 June 2009}}
In December 2014, the [[United States Department of Labor|U.S. Department of Labor]] issued a ''[[List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor]]'' that mentioned [[Angola]], the [[Central African Republic]], the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Guinea]], [[Liberia]], and [[Sierra Leone]] as part of the 74 countries with significant incidence of [[child labor]] and [[forced labor]] as far as the diamond industry is concerned.[http://www.dol.gov/ilab/reports/child-labor/list-of-goods/ List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor] == Working conditions == {{Refimprove|date=September 2009}} Child Slave Labor News argued that it is reported that in the late 1980s, about 11% and in 1994, 16% of the workforce was underage in diamond industry. "Currently{{Clarify|date=September 2009}} there are over 171 million children that work in hazardous work sites such as factories and mines."{{cite web|url=http://ihscslnews.org/view_article.php?id=162|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130114031418/http://ihscslnews.org/view_article.php?id=162|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-01-14|date=November 2006|title=Diamonds Are Forever, But Not The Lives Of Child Workers|quote=}} CSLN further argued the diamond mines are dangerous work sites, "open pits of heavy minerals, oil, machinery exhaust, and any other rubbish seeps into". It is reported that diamond miners are exposed health risks and hazards, including [[malaria]], [[dysentery]], [[cholera]] and [[sexual diseases]].{{cite book|last=Yakovleva|first=Natalia|title=Corporate social responsibility in the mining industries|publisher=Ashgate Publishing|year=2005|page=79|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7CDqXX_28lkC | isbn=978-0-7546-4268-8}} In addition to those diseases, child labourers who are subjected to working in poor conditions including overcrowding, abuse, long work hours and cheap pay in diamond mines suffer from [[eye strain]], [[headache]]s, [[malnutrition]], and respiratory problems. While they are paid for how many diamonds they can polish or cut per day. The ordinary amount of money a worker will get for polishing the uppermost section of a diamond is two [[rupee]]s, which is below eight US [[Cent (United States coin)|cent]]s, while workers who make smaller diamonds, might be paid 15 to 20 [[US dollar]]s per week. Child slaves in [[Surat]] sleep in their workplace or in a small hovel instead of a home. The [[International Confederation of Free Trade Unions]] has claimed that child labour was prospering in the diamond industry in Western India, where the majority of the world's diamonds are cut and polished while workers are often paid only a fraction of 1% of the value of the stones they cut in 1997. Child workers are used as slaves since business owners exploit them as cheap employment to raise more profit and diamond industry is "an infamous venue of exploitation towards youth workers" like mines and sweatshops in South Africa or India while the diamond is overpriced and funded for wars. The majority of the [[third world country]] families are [[Poverty|poor]] therefore rely on their children’s income to survive. Additionally since most children do not have the opportunity to gain an education from their local school system, working at a [[sweatshop]] is their only option in life. In other instances, employers pays the family in advance and in turn, the child works to pay off the debt, which is called bonding, yet bonded children cannot pay their family’s debt because of interest. With the increase in owed money, bonded children are forced into a life of servitude which will pass onto their descendants. On the other hand, Civil wars usually shut down all government services. Countries like [[Sierra Leone]], which depend on [[diamond]]s for much of its economic activity, not only face disruption in production (which reduces the supply), but also a thriving [[black market]] in [[conflict diamond]]s, which drives down the price for what diamonds are produced. == Forceful relocation of indigenous Bushman people by DeBeers == When the mines are located on the land indigenous people including children, they had to be moved to a different area in order to construct a mine to collect gems. In [[Botswana]], a long dispute has existed between the interests of the mining company, [[De Beers]], and the [[Population transfer|relocation]] of the [[bushmen|Bushman]] [[tribe]] from the land in order to explore diamond resources. The Bushmen have been facing threats from government policies since at least 1980, when the diamond resources were discovered.[http://www.survival-international.org/tribes/bushmen The Bushmen Need You] A campaign is being fought in an attempt to bring an end to what [[Survival International]] considers to be a "[[genocide]]" of a tribe that has been living in those lands for tens of thousands of years.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2919089/De-Beers-battles-with-Survival.html |title=De Beers battles with Survival |work=Telegraph |date=2005-07-17 |accessdate=2009-07-23 | location=London}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/2793779.stm |title=Bushmen 'moved for diamonds' |publisher=BBC news |date=2003-02-24 |accessdate=2009-07-23 | first=Alastair | last=Leithead}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2005-07-08-botswana-diamonds-lose-their-sparkle |title=Botswana diamonds lose their sparkle |work=Mail and Guardian |date=2005-07-08 |accessdate=2009-07-23}} On the grounds that their hunting and gathering has become "obsolete" and their presence is no longer compatible with "preserving [[wildlife]] resources", they were persecuted by the government in order to make them leave the [[nature reserve|reserve]]. To get rid of them, they have had their [[water supplies]] cut off, they have been taxed, fined, beaten and [[torture]]d.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2003/aug/05/comment.conservation |title=Driven out of Eden |work=The Guardian |date=2003-08-05 |accessdate=2009-07-23 | location=London | first=George | last=Monbiot}} Several international [[supermodel]]s, including [[Iman (model)|Iman]], [[Lily Cole]] and [[Erin O'Connor]], who were previously involved with advertising for the companies' diamonds, have backed down after realizing the consequences raised by this scandal, and now support the campaign.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/kalahari-bushmen-win-ancestral-land-case-428366.html |title=Kalahari Bushmen win ancestral land case |work=The Independent |date=2006-12-14 |accessdate=2009-07-23 | location=London}} == Cultural depictions == {{Main|Diamonds from Sierra Leone}} On 4 July 2005 [[United States|American]] [[hip hop music|rap]] star [[Kanye West]], released a song titled [[Diamonds from Sierra Leone]] as the lead single of his second studio album, ''[[Late Registration]]'',{{cite AV media notes |others=Kanye West |title=Late Registration |year=2005 |publisher=Roc-A-Fella Records |id=}} containing a repeated sample of the [[theme song]] for the 1971 [[James Bond]] film, ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]'' as performed by [[Shirley Bassey]].{{cite web |url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2007/10/29/shirley_bassey_wants_to_work_with_kanye_ |title=Shirley Bassey Wants To Work With Kanye West |accessdate=2007-10-29 |author=World Entertainment News Network |date=2007-10-29 |work=Starpulsec.com |publisher=Starpulse}} The song is revealing the hard life of child workers in Sierra Leone, like other [[West African]] nations who since 1991 having been forced to mine [[conflict diamonds]] and die in [[civil war]]s financed by them: "''Good Morning! This ain't Vietnam. Still, people lose hands, legs, arms for real/Little was known of Sierra Leone, and how it connect to the diamonds we own...''".{{cite web |author=Crosley, Hillary|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1504091/20050614/index.jhtml?headlines=true |title='Diamonds' Remix: Kanye Raps About Rocks, Jay Raps About Roc |accessdate=2005-06-14 |author2=Aswad, Jem |date=2005-06-14 |work=[[MTV]] |publisher=[[MTV Networks]]}} The [[music video]] was directed by [[Hype Williams]] and shot entirely in black-and-white in Prague,{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1502507/20050517/west_kanye.jhtml |title=Kanye West Shooting 'Diamonds' Video In 'Pray-Goo' |accessdate=2005-05-17 |author=Reid, Shaheem |date=2005-05-17 |work=MTV |publisher=MTV Networks}} featuring visuals of young African children toiling away in mines under the careful watch of their wardens with juxtaposed with scenes of wealthy Westerners shopping in boutiques and trying on jewellery. The song peaked at number forty-three on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], was moderately successful on the [[iTunes]] music service, and peaked in the eight spot on the [[UK Top 40]]. It won a [[Grammy Award]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Rap Solo Performance|Best Rap Song]] at the [[48th Grammy Awards]]. == See also == * [[Blood diamond]] ** [[Blood Diamonds (documentary)]] ** [[Blood Diamond (film)]] * [[Mining industry of Angola#Environmental impacts of diamond mining|Mining industry of Angola]] * [[Child labour in India#Diamond industry]] == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2009/06/26/zimbabwe-end-repression-marange-diamond-fields * http://www.ilo.org/dyn/clsurvey/lfsurvey.list?p_lang=en&p_country=ZW * http://allafrica.com/stories/200904100726.html * https://web.archive.org/web/20090513095730/http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/sweat/zimbabwe.htm * https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gYqxYwQnE1jmgsg2b07dutMefNJQ * http://www.wsws.org/articles/2002/oct2002/cong-o26.shtml ; Working and living conditions of miners and local people * http://www.ddiglobal.org/contentDocuments/DDI-Gender-Backgrounder-May-2009-en.PDF * https://web.archive.org/web/20071215131737/http://www.afrol.com/Countries/DRC/documents/un_resources_2002_govt_zim.htm ; India * https://web.archive.org/web/20120301123106/http://www.lex.unict.it/eurolabor/ricerca/altri_wp/econ_impact_child.pdf page 14 ; Africa * http://www.pacweb.org/Documents/annual-reviews-diamonds/SierraLeone_AR_2004-Eng.pdf * http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=917227 [[Category:Diamond industry]] [[Category:Child labour]] [[Category:Labour relations in India]] [[Category:Mining in Sierra Leone]] [[Category:Child labour in India]] [[Category:Mining in Guinea]] [[Category:Diamond industry in India]]

'''Costimator''' is an American-based series of [[Cost Estimating software]] developed by Thomas Charkiewicz in 1982 and is designed to model manufacturing costs.<ref name="amazon">{{cite book|last=Smock|first=Douglas|title=On-Demand Supply Management: World Class Strategies, Practices, and Technology|year=2007|publisher=J. Ross Publishing|isbn=1932159622|pages=128|url=https://www.amazon.com/On-demand-Supply-Management-World-class-Strategies/dp/1932159622}}</ref> The software is designed, developed and marketed by MTI of [[West Springfield, Massachusetts|West Springfield, MA.]]
== History ==
Costimator was designed by Thomas Charkiewicz, a former machinist and manufacturing manager who studied computer-aided manufacturing at the [[University of Massachusetts]]. Costimator was released in late 1982,<ref name="amazon" /> designed to model manufacturing costs.
In 2002, [[IBM]] bought Costimator OEM from MTI Systems, Inc.<ref name="amazon_a">{{cite book|last=Smock|first=Douglas|title=On-Demand Supply Management: World Class Strategies, Practices, and Technology|year=2007|publisher=J. Ross Publishing|isbn=1932159622|pages=132|url=https://www.amazon.com/On-demand-Supply-Management-World-class-Strategies/dp/1932159622}}</ref> Many of the products on the market focused on machine shop operations. Costimator had its roots in the machining industry, but later branched out to include several other manufacturing processes.
John Kagan, the former manager of PC Cost Management at IBM and [[Lenovo]] estimated that between 2003 and 2004, IBM saved more than $10 million using Costimator.<ref name="amazon_a" />
Costimator also includes a function known as IQ builder which customers can use to model their own manufacturing process based on historical data. The data was derived from the company’s customers in addition to various independent industry sources. Labor costs come from the [[U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Smock|first=Douglas|title=On-Demand Supply Management: World Class Strategies, Practices, and Technology|year=2007|publisher=J. Ross Publishing|isbn=1932159622|pages=133|url=https://www.amazon.com/On-demand-Supply-Management-World-class-Strategies/dp/1932159622}}</ref>
In 2009, MTI Systems, Inc. reached an agreement with European distributor Premier Manufacturing Solutions, LTD (Stockport, UK) to market its flagship products Costimator OEM and Costimator JS to companies throughout Europe.<ref>{{cite web|title=www.mtisystems.com/press_room/press_releases/press_apr_09.html|url=http://www.mtisystems.com/press_room/press_releases/press_apr_09.html|accessdate=23 August 2012}}</ref> In February 2011, Cimtronics and MTI Systems, Inc. also agreed to terms on a distribution partnership.<ref>{{cite web|title=MTI Systems Announces Channel Agreement with Cimtronics|url=http://www.mtisystems.com/press_room/press_releases/press_Mar_11_1.html|accessdate=23 August 2012}}</ref>

Lasky | known_for = co-founder of Altman, Stoller, Weiss | religion = | occupation = Advertising executive | children = Emily Altman Heaps
Dara Altman Lennon | parents = | family = }} '''David R. Altman''' (1915-August 30, 2000) was an American advertising executive who co-founded the ''Altman, Stoller, Weiss'' advertising agency.[https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/08/business/david-r-altman-85-is-dead-his-ads-built-several-brands.html New York Times: "David R. Altman, 85, Is Dead; His Ads Built Several Brands" by Mary Williams Walsh] September 8, 2000[http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-09-12/news/0009120286_1_altman-household-names-north-alabama Baltimore Sun: "David R. Altman, 85, a fashion advertising executive who built several obscure clothing lines into household names, died Aug. 30 in New York"] September 12, 2000 ==Biography== Born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family,[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/advertising Jewish Virtual Library: "Modern Jewish History: Advertising"] retrieved May 4, 2017 Altman served as an Army weapons instructor during [[World War II]]. After the war, he attended [[New York University School of Law]] at night on the [[G.I. Bill]]. While in school, he worked during the day as the advertising director for the trade magazine, ''The Women's Reporter.'' Although he earned a law degree, he instead accepted a job as an account executive with the fashion house, Irving Serwer Advertising. In 1950, he founded Altman & Stoller with fellow Irving Serwer alumni [[Max Stoller]] where he served as chairman.[https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/10/obituaries/max-stoller.html New York Times: "Obituary: Max Stoller"] May 10, 1982 Altman focused on the fashion industry which was ripe for development as most clothing manufacturers typically pitched their concepts direct to the stores rather than develop the brand with the general public. Through his ad campaigns, Altman was credited with transforming then unknown fashion brands into household names. He developed the [[Wrangler (jeans)|Wrangler jeans]] brand with ads that promised that the jeans would fade exactly how teenagers wanted them. He transitioned Monet jewelry from being perceived as low-cost to a premier brand by photographing inexpensive pieces on supermodels. He promoted the [[Russ Togs]] brand with a red neon sign the read ''RRRRRRRRRuss Toggs'' at the entrance to the [[Queens–Midtown Tunnel|Midtown Tunnel]] in [[Manhattan]], elongating the name into a sexy purr. His creed was "Find your character; create your character; concentrate on your character." In 1955, the firm became ''Altman, Stoller, and Chalk'' with the addition of [[Howard W. Chalk]] as a partner; Chalk left the company to start ''Chalk, Nissen, Hanft''.[https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/19/business/howard-w-chalk-76-former-ad-executive.html New York Times: "Howard W. Chalk, 76, Former Ad Executive"] December 19, 1998 The firm became ''Altman, Stoller, Weiss'' in the mid 1970s after Melvin D. Weiss joined the firm. The firm then diversified out of fashion advertising winning accounts with the Spanish tourist board, Ezo denture adhesive, and Lanson champagne, and handled the introduction of [[Newsweek]]'s [[Inside Sports]] magazine. In 1978, he published an editorial in the New York Times that he was sickened by what television advertising had done to election campaigns which often promoted mediocre candidates stating "'A candidate is not a can of soup." Altman, Stoller, Weiss was later purchased by Nadler & Larimer Advertising where it was maintained as a subsidiary before being fully absorbed and the name retired in 1983.[https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/04/business/advertising-nadler-larimer-absorbing-subsidiaries.html New York Times: "ADVERTISING; Nadler & Larimer Absorbing Subsidiaries" By Philip H. Dougherty] August 4, 1983 Altman became an executive vice president at Nadler & Larimer. ==Personal life== He was married to Floria V. Lasky; they had two daughters, Emily Altman Heaps and Dara Altman Lennon.[https://www.nytimes.com/1985/06/17/style/emily-m-altman-marries-alan-heaps.html New York Times: "Emily M. Altman Marries Alan Heaps"] June 17, 1985[https://www.nytimes.com/1988/04/24/style/dara-f-altman-is-married.html New York Times: "Dara F. Altman Is Married"] April 24, 1988 ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Altman, David R.}} [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:2000 deaths]] [[Category:American Jews]]

Dimash is one of the richest young men of [[Kazakhstan]] and is an heir to the fortune of one of Kazakhstan's wealthiest families.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1683601-dimash-adilet-biografiya-roditeli.html|title=Димаш Адилет: биография и родители|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-25|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.therichest.com/expensive-lifestyle/money/12-outrageous-rich-kid-instagram-accounts-you-need-to-follow/|title=12 Outrageous Rich Kids Instagram Accounts You Need to Follow|last=|first=|date=|work=TheRichest|access-date=2018-11-25|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.townandcountry.ph/people/money-power/10-real-life-crazy-rich-asians-a1934-20170805-lfrm2?utm_source=Facebook-TC&utm_medium=Ownshare&utm_campaign=20170805-fbnp-money-power-rich-asians-fbfirst|title=9 Real-Life Crazy Rich Asians|last=|first=|date=|work=Town and Country Magazine|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wolipop.detik.com/foto-entertainment/d-4220047/tajir-dari-lahir-inilah-sosok-si-ganteng-dimash-putra-konglomerat/4|title=Tajir Dari Lahir! Inilah Sosok Si Ganteng Dimash, Putra Konglomerat|last=|first=|date=|work=Detik.com|access-date=2018-11-25|language=Indonesian}}</ref> Adilet is an alumni of [[Harvard University]] and is known to be the first [[Kazakhs|Kazakh]] member of [[Mensa International]], with a reported [[Intelligence quotient|IQ]] of over 150 (over 99th percentile on the [[Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scales|Stanford-Binet intelligence scales]])<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://tengrinews.kz/kazakhstan_news/kazahstanets-voshel-v-chislo-samyih-umnyih-lyudey-na-planete-292199/|title=Казахстанец вошел в число самых умных людей на планете|website=Tengrinews.kz|language=ru|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.zakon.kz/4785332-kazakhstanskogo-dendi-dimasha-adilenta.html|title=Казахстанского денди Димаша Адилета пригласили в клуб умнейших людей планеты|website=Zakon.kz|language=ru|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1093945-camogo-zavidnogo-zhenikha-kazakhstanca-p.html|title=Самый завидный жених Казахстана попал в клуб умнейших людей планеты|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-25|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://comode.kz/post/nashi-za-rubezhom/chem-zhivet-kazahstanets-v-zheneve-10-interesnyh-myslej-dimasha-adileta/|title=Чем живет казахстанец в Женеве: 10 интересных мыслей Димаша Адилета {{!}} женский портал Comode|last=|first=|date=|website=Comode.kz|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://informburo.kz/novosti/zavidnyy-zhenih-iz-kazahstana-priznan-odnim-iz-samyh-umnyh-lyudey-v-mire.html|title=Завидный жених из Казахстана признан одним из самых умных людей в мире|last=|first=|date=|work=InformBuro.kz|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref>
Dimash is known for his activity on the social media platform [[Instagram]], where he shares content with an audience of around 1 million people. He is one of the most followed male influencers in [[Switzerland]] and [[Kazakhstan]], cooperating with such brands as [[Audemars Piguet]] and [[Lamborghini]].<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3368810/Meet-rich-boys-Instagram-spend-40-000-night-hotel-suites-500-000-bags-shoes.html|title=Meet the rich boys of Instagram who spend thousands on bags and shoes|last=|first=|date=|work=Mail Online (Dailymail.co.uk)|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://cosmo.kz/dimash-adilet-o-sebe-i-svoem-otnoshenii-k-devushkam/|title=Димаш Адилет о себе и своем отношении к девушкам|last=|first=|date=|work=Cosmopolitan Magazine|access-date=2018-11-25|language=ru-RU}}</ref> Dimash is an avid collector of luxury watches, cars, and motorcycles.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=https://firstclasse.com.my/rich-heirs-on-instagram-dimash-adilet/|title=Rich Heirs on Instagram: Dimash Adilet, Kazakhstan’s top Internet personality|last=|first=|date=|work=FirstClasse|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://365info.kz/2016/02/odin-iz-15-samyh-populyarnyh-kazahstantsev-dimash-adilet/|title=Один из 15 самых популярных казахстанцев: Димаш Адилет - 365info.kz|last=|first=|date=|website=365info.kz|language=ru-KZ|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref> In 2016, he was named as one of the "50 most successful men on the internet" by [[L'Officiel Hommes]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hommes.kz/blog/2016/05/24/lofficiel-hommes-sovmestno-s-hackett-london-predstavlyayut-50-uspeshnyh-muzhchin-v-seti/|title=Hackett London представляет "50 успешных мужчин в сети"|last=|first=|date=|website=L'Officiel Hommes|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref>
Due to his extravagant lifestyle and the attention he receives online from the members of the opposite sex, the media nicknamed Dimash as "The Real-Life [[Christian Gray|Christian Grey]]" and "Kazakhstan's [[Eligible bachelor|Most Eligible Bachelor]]".<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ntk.kz/ru/revu/2017-03-07/samyj-zavidnyj-zhenix-kazaxstana-dimash-adilet-dal-sovety-kak-ugodit-devushke-364|title=Самый завидный жених Казахстана Димаш Адилет дал советы, как угодить девушке|last=|first=|date=|website=НТК Channel|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://365info.kz/2016/02/kazahstanskij-kristian-grej/|title=Казахстанский Кристиан Грей - 365info.kz|last=|first=|date=|website=365info.kz|language=ru-KZ|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1409697-samyy-zhelannyy-zhenikh-kazakhstana-rask.html|title=Самый желанный жених Казахстана раскритиковал День святого Валентина|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-25|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://express-k.kz/news/shoubiz/instagram_zvezda_dimash_adilet_pokazal_50_ottenkov_serogo_v_gonkonge-127166|title=Инстаграм-звезда Димаш Адилет показал 50 оттенков серого в Гонконге|last=|first=|date=|website=express-k.kz|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://365info.kz/2018/08/otechestvennuyu-barbi-i-kazahstanskogo-kristiana-greya-nazvali-samoj-krasivoj-paroj/|title=Отечественную Барби и казахстанского Кристиана Грея назвали самой красивой парой - 365info.kz|last=|first=|date=|website=365info.kz|language=ru-KZ|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref>
Dimash speaks fluently in [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[Russian language|Russian]], and currently resides in [[Geneva|Geneva, Switzerland]].<ref name=":2" />
== Early life and Education == Dimash Adilet was born on May 17, 1995, in [[Almaty|Almaty, Kazakhstan]]. He is the eldest son in the family.
At the age of 11, Dimash was sent to study in a private boarding school in [[Gstaad|Gstaad, Switzerland]], away from his family.<ref name=":0" /> In 2010 he attended a private boarding school and sports academy [[IMG Academy]] in [[Bradenton, Florida]] for a year, before returning to [[Switzerland]] to graduate from high school. Dimash is an alumni of [[Harvard University]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> His academic background is in [[Finance]] and [[Psychology]].<ref name=":13" />
During his school years, Dimash was competing in Swiss National [[Giant slalom|Ski Racing]] competitions, and at the age of 14, he passed the qualification for the skill-level of a professional Swiss ski instructor. Dimash was a decorated member of his high school's [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]] team. He also engaged in [[Boxing|competitive boxing]] since the age of 14.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":12" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1758364-samyj-zelannyj-zenih-kazahstana-opisal-svou-budusuu-zenu.html|title=Самый желанный жених Казахстана описал свою будущую жену|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-26|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://food.detik.com/foto-kuliner/d-4227343/mengintip-anak-konglomerat-kazakhstan-dimas-adilet-saat-masak-dan-kulineran/9/#photos|title=Mengintip Anak Konglomerat Kazakhstan, Dimas Adilet Saat Masak dan Kulineran|last=|first=|date=|work=DetikFood|access-date=2018-11-27|language=Indonesian}}</ref>
He has been noted to have constantly gotten into fights at school, although always forgiven thanks to his outstanding academic performance.<ref name=":2" />
== Career == [[File:Dimash Adilet and Stefano Domenicali.jpg|thumb|right|Dimash Adilet and [[Lamborghini]] CEO [[Stefano Domenicali]]]] Dimash Adilet currently has around 1 million followers across his social media profiles. He first started gaining popularity on [[Instagram]] in 2015 for sharing snapshots of his luxury lifestyle and "refined" sense of fashion<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Lifestyle/rkoi-rich-kids-instagram-documentary-shows-lavish-lives/story?id=35917467|title=#RKOI: Film Documents Lavish Lives of Wealthy Youth|last=|first=|date=|website=ABC News|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref>, along with [[Philosophy|philosophical]] writing and inspirational captions on the subjects such as life, love, staying positive and treating each other with respect.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":7" /> With his online content, he is aiming to motivate the younger generation and act as a [[role model]] to encourage [[Personal development|personal]] and [[Intelligence|intellectual]] growth of the youth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tengrinews.kz/cinema/kazahstantsa-priglasili-snyatsya-britanskom-filme-Instagram-278345/|title=Казахстанца пригласили сняться в британском фильме об Instagram|website=Tengrinews.kz|language=ru|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref> Dimash is also known to often promote positive social impact and advocate for [[environmental protection]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kaz.nur.kz/838153-qazaq-zhigiti-aghylshyn-filmine-tusuge.html|title=Қазақ жігіті ағылшын фильміне түсуге шақырту алды (фото)|last=NUR.KZ|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-26|language=kk-KZ}}</ref>
In 2016, Dimash became the first [[Kazakhs|Kazakh]] member of [[Mensa International]], after scoring in the upper 99th percentile ([[Stanford–Binet Intelligence Scales|Stanford-Binet intelligence scales]]) on an official supervised IQ test, recording an [[Intelligence quotient|IQ]] of over 150. This lead to widespread news coverage of the topic in Kazakhstan and a subsequent increase in Dimash's online following.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":2" /> Other big increases in his following are attributed to various TV appearances, magazine photoshoots, media coverage, and organic follower growth.
Dimash's social media influence led to him cooperating with such brands as [[Audemars Piguet]] and [[Lamborghini]], among others. As a fashion [[Influencer marketing|influencer]], and a model, he often travels to [[Fashion week|Fashion Week]] events around the world, as well as other high-profile events.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gaytimes.co.uk/style/99643/spotted-the-best-dressed-boys-at-lfw/|title=Spotted: The best dressed boys at London Fashion Week|date=2018-02-19|work=Gay Times|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-5270829/Rich-Kids-Instagram-beat-Blue-Monday.html|title=Rich Kids of Instagram show how they beat Blue Monday|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref>
Dimash Adilet is also engaged in his [[family business]] as well as his personal business.<ref name=":0" />
== Personal Life == In 2015, Dimash was reportedly involved in a short-lasting relationship with [[Miss Universe]] 2014 [[Paulina Vega]] after her visit to Kazakhstan, documented on both Adilet's and Vega's [[instagram]] accounts.
He is currently not married. Because of Dimash's young age, fame, and wealth, the media often refer to him as "Kazakhstan's Most [[Eligible bachelor|Eligible Bachelor]]" and "The Real-Life [[Christian Grey]]".<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1093967-shikarnaya-zhizn-samogo-zhelannogo-zheni.html|title=Шикарная жизнь самого желанного жениха Казахстана|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-26|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zakon.kz/4844275-samyjj-zavidnyjj-zhenikh-kazakhstana.html#|title=Самый завидный жених Казахстана раскритиковал День Святого Валентина|website=Zakon.kz|language=ru|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref> He has been cited by many sources to be [[Physical attractiveness|physically attractive]], and is said to receive a lot of female attention on his social media profiles.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11" /><ref name=":9" /><ref name=":13" /> When asked how important it is for a man to be good-looking, during an interview for the [[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan Magazine]], Dimash stated: "Looks are subjective and looks are by far not what's most important for a man. A man should be intelligent, educated, honest, confident, dependable, and generous. Looks only come after all of these."<ref name=":2" />
Dimash is cited to consider family and healthy relationships to be central to a man's happiness. He also strongly dislikes the idea of [[infidelity]]. <ref name=":2" />

[[Image:Albuquerque aerial.jpg|thumb|Downtown Albuquerque aerial]]
'''Downtown Albuquerque''' is the [[central business district]] of [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]], [[New Mexico]]. It is where a large number of the city's [[highrise]] buildings are located, as well as being the center of government and business for the region.
Downtown is roughly defined as the area between Marble Avenue, Coal Avenue, Sixth Street, and the [[New Mexico Rail Runner Express]] railroad tracks. The area on the east side of the railroad tracks is known as '''East Downtown''' or '''EDo'''.
==Street grid== Downtown Albuquerque is laid out in a standard grid pattern, with numbered north-south ''streets'' and named east-west ''avenues''. [[Central Avenue (Albuquerque)|Central Avenue]] (originally known as Railroad Avenue) is the main east-west thoroughfare through the center of Downtown, while Lomas Boulevard (originally New York Avenue) is a major east-west arterial through the north part of downtown.
The streets start with First Street just west of the railroad tracks and increase in number moving westward. Fourth Street was originally the main north-south thoroughfare through Downtown but today it is discontinuous, interrupted by Civic Plaza. The two block stretch between Central and Civic Plaza was once converted into a pedestrian mall, but was reverted to a vehicular roadway in late 2014.<ref>https://www.cabq.gov/council/find-your-councilor/district-2/projects-planning-efforts-district-2/4th-street-mall-conversion 4th Street Mall Conversion - City Of Albuquerque</ref> Since these developments took place Second Street has been the main north-south street through downtown.
Fourth Street through downtown Albuquerque was part of [[U.S. Route 66]] prior to the route's 1937 realignment. Afterwards, Route 66 ran along Central Avenue until its decommissioning.
==Districts== Downtown Albuquerque is divided into six official '''districts''', which are identified by a unified system of signage and icons.
===Courthouse District=== Located on the north side of downtown, this district is bounded by Marble Avenue, Roma Avenue, Second Street, and Seventh Street. It is named for the three major courthouses located at the intersection of Fourth and Lomas: [[Pete V. Domenici United States Courthouse]], Bernalillo County Courthouse, and the Bernalillo County [[Metropolitan Courthouse]].
===Warehouse District=== [[File:Santa Fe Freight House, Albuquerque.jpg|thumb|Old [[Santa Fe Railroad]] Freight House in 2007, Transportation Center District.]] On the north side of downtown along the railroad tracks, the Warehouse District includes the area between Second and the railroad tracks, north of the Convention Center to Slate Avenue. As its name implies, this area contains mostly warehouses from the railroad era.
===Plaza District=== The Plaza District is the central area of downtown, bounded by Roma, Copper, Seventh, and the railroad tracks. It is centered on Civic Plaza and includes many of Albuquerque's large office and government buildings including the Albuquerque City-County Building, the Convention Center, [[Albuquerque Plaza]], the [[Compass Bank Building (Albuquerque)|Compass Bank Building]], and the [[Albuquerque Petroleum Building]]. The Main Library of the [[Albuquerque/Bernalillo County Library System]] is also located in this district.
===Arts and Entertainment District=== This district is centered along Central Avenue and Gold Avenue east of First Street. It contains most of downtown Albuquerque's historic buildings as well as most of its shopping, dining, and nightlife destinations. Notable landmarks in this district include the [[KiMo Theater]], [[Occidental Life Building]], [[First National Bank Building (Albuquerque)|First National Bank Building]], and [[Sunshine Building]]. There is a small concentration of government and office buildings on Gold Avenue which includes the [[Dennis Chavez Federal Building]], [[Gold Building]], and [[Simms Building]]. [[Amy Biehl High School]] is also located in this district.
===Transportation Center District=== This is the smallest district, encompassing the area south of Central Avenue and east of First Street. Most of the district is occupied by [[Alvarado Transportation Center]].
===Casa District=== The southernmost part of downtown, the Casa District includes the area between Gold and Coal Avenue, extending all the way west to Tenth Street. This is a primarily residential district, with a large number of [[loft apartment]] buildings. Alvarado Square, the location of the [[PNM Building]] and the headquarters of [[Bernalillo County]], is also located in the Casa District.
[[Image:Old Albuquerque High School Albuquerque.jpg|thumb|right|Old Albuquerque High School]]
==EDo== Not one of the official downtown districts, EDo (East Downtown) is a small but expanding neighborhood centered on Central and Broadway on the east side of the railroad tracks, bounded roughly by the railroad tracks on the west, [[I-25]] on the east, Coal on the south, and Martin Luther King Avenue on the north. EDo is a trendy area containing several loft apartment buildings and a number of small shops and restaurants. The focal point of EDo is the renovated [[Old Albuquerque High School]] campus, which is now a residential complex. The name "EDo" was coined in imitation of the [[LoDo]] area of [[Denver]] which in turn was an imitation of [[SoHo]] and [[TriBeCa]] in [[New York City]] .
==Buildings==
===Tallest buildings=== Downtown Albuquerque contains most of the city's highrise buildings, including the four tallest. The tallest downtown buildings are listed below:
{| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Rank !! Name !! Height !! Floors |- | 1 | [[Albuquerque Plaza]] | {{convert|351|ft|m|0}} | 22 |- | 2 | [[Hyatt Regency Albuquerque]] | {{convert|256|ft|m|0}} | 21 |- | 3 | [[Compass Bank Building (Albuquerque)|Compass Bank Building]] | {{convert|238|ft|m|0}} | 18 |- | 4 | [[500 Marquette]] | {{convert|235|ft|m|0}} | 15 |- | 5 | [[New Mexico Bank & Trust Building]] | {{convert|203|ft|m|0}} | 14 |}
===Historic landmarks=== [[Image:KiMo Albuquerque.jpg|thumb|right|[[KiMo Theater]]]] There are a number of buildings in downtown that are on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]: * [[KiMo Theater]], one of the city's best-known landmarks * The old [[Federal Building and United States Courthouse (Albuquerque, New Mexico)|Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse]] * [[First National Bank Building (Albuquerque, New Mexico)|First National Bank Building]] * [[Hotel Andaluz]] * [[Occidental Life Building]] * [[Old Post Office (Albuquerque, New Mexico)|Old Post Office]] * [[Simms Building]] * [[Southwestern Brewery and Ice Company]] * [[Sunshine Building]]
==Transportation== [[Image:Alvarado Transportation Center.jpg|thumb|right|Alvarado Transportation Center]] Downtown is the center of public transit in the city, and is served by a network of [[ABQ RIDE]] routes including local routes, the [[Albuquerque Rapid Transit]] [[Bus rapid transit|BRT]] route, and the [[Rapid Ride]] express routes, most of which include stops at the [[Alvarado Transportation Center]]. ABQ RIDE also operates a free circulator bus service in the downtown area named Downtown Get Around (or "D-Ride" for short) which runs from 6:30 am to 7:00 pm every 7 minutes on weekdays. D-Ride service will end on May 12, 2018, and will be replaced by various local routes, such as 12th Street/Rio Grande (routes #36 and #37) and Menaul (route #8). All inbound routes to the [[Alvarado Transportation Center]], except route #66 and [[Rapid Ride]] routes, will have a fare-free zone.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cabq.gov/transit/news/abq-ride-implementing-route-and-schedule-changes-on-may-12|title=ABQ RIDE Implementing Route and Schedule Changes on May 12|website=City of Albuquerque|language=en|access-date=2018-04-28}}</ref>
In addition to local bus transit, the Alvarado Transportation Center also incorporates [[Amtrak]] and [[Greyhound bus]] facilities, as well as a stop on the [[New Mexico Rail Runner Express]] [[commuter rail]] line. The [[New Mexico Rail Runner Express|rail runner express]] provides commuter service seven days a week along a 96.5-mile corridor that runs through multiple counties in New Mexico through 13 stations.

{{about|the Canadian racing driver}} {{Infobox F1 driver | image = | name = George Eaton | nationality = {{flagicon|CAN}} Canadian | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|11|12|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada | Years = {{F1|1969}} – {{F1|1971}} | Team(s) = [[BRM]] | Races = 13 (11 starts) | Championships = 0 | Wins = 0 | Podiums = 0 | Points = 0 | Poles = 0 | Fastest laps = 0 | First race = [[1969 United States Grand Prix]] | First win = | Last win = | Last race = [[1971 Canadian Grand Prix]] }} '''George Ross Eaton''' (born 12 November 1945) is a Canadian former racing driver who is a member of the prominent [[Eaton family]]. ==Life and career== Eaton was born in [[Toronto]], he is the youngest son of [[John David Eaton|John]] and [[Signy Hildur Stefansson Eaton|Signy Eaton]]. He gained attention as a Canadian race driver who participated in [[Can Am]], [[Formula One]] and [[Formula 5000|Formula A]] races. He served as president of the [[Eaton's|family company]] for ten years. Under his leadership, Eaton's continued its precipitous decline from its historic dominance in the Canadian retail market. His Formula One career with [[British Racing Motors]] included 13 World Championship Grands Prix and one non-Championship race, debuting on 5 October 1969. He scored no championship points. Eaton raced in the Can-Am series in 1968, 69 and 70. He was the top Canadian in the Can-Am Series in 1969. He participated in the Canadian Formula A series in 1969 and the Continental Series in 1969 and 1971 but retired from racing after 1972.{{cite web|url=http://autoweek.com/article/car-news/where-are-they-now-snapshot-speed-lives-fates-40-years-after-riversides-1968-can-am|title=Where are they now?: Snapshot of speed: Lives & fates 40 years after Riverside's 1968 Can-Am|work=Autoweek|accessdate=17 April 2016}} He was inducted into the [[Canadian Motorsport Hall of Fame]] in 1994. ==Complete Formula One World Championship results== ([[:Template:F1 driver results legend 2|key]]) {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:90%" ! {{Infobox Officeholder | name = Gyude Bryant | image = File:Gyude Bryant 2004.jpg | order = Chairman of the Transitional Government of Liberia | office = | deputy = [[Wesley Momo Johnson]] | term_start = 14 October 2003 | term_end = 16 January 2006 | predecessor = [[Moses Blah]] | successor = [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]] | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1949|1|17}} | birth_place = [[Monrovia, Liberia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2014|4|16|1949|1|17}} | death_place = [[Monrovia, Liberia]] | nationality = Liberian | party = [[Liberian Action Party]] }} '''Charles Gyude Bryant''' (17 January 1949 – 16 April 2014) was a [[Liberia]]n politician and businessman. He served as the Chairman of the Transitional Government of Liberia from 14 October 2003 to 16 January 2006. The installation of the transitional government was part of the peace agreement to end the country's [[Second Liberian Civil War|second civil war]], which had raged since the [[Liberians United for Reconciliation and Democracy]] (LURD) rebelled against President [[Charles Taylor (Liberian politician)|Charles Taylor]] in 1999. Bryant was previously a businessman and was chosen as chairman because he was seen as politically neutral and therefore acceptable to each of the warring factions, which included LURD, the [[Movement for Democracy in Liberia]] (MODEL), and loyalists of former President Taylor. He is a prominent member of the [[Episcopal Church of Liberia]], and was critical of the governments of [[Samuel Doe]] (1980–90) and Taylor (1997–2003).
[[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]] won the [[Liberian general election, 2005|2005 elections]] and took office in January 2006, succeeding Bryant.
He died on 16 April 2014 at the [[John F. Kennedy Medical Center (Liberia)|John F. Kennedy Medical Center]] in [[Monrovia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Charles Gyude Bryant, Former Liberia Interim President is Dead|url=http://www.frontpageafricaonline.com/index.php/news/1362-charles-gyude-bryant-former-liberia-interim-president-is-dead|newspaper=[[FrontPage Africa]]|date=16 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Butty|first=James|title=Gyude Bryant, Liberia’s Sixth Transitional Leader, Dies at 65|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/liberia-transitional-leader-gyude-bryant-dies-at-age-65/1895183.html|newspaper=[[Voice of America]]|date=April 17, 2014}}</ref>
==Embezzlement== In January 2007, Bryant was questioned by police regarding allegations of corruption during his time in office.<ref>Jonathan Paye-Layleh, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6278909.stm "Liberia ex-leader probed on graft"], ''[[BBC News Online]]'', 19 January 2007.</ref> On 27 February 2007, Bryant was charged with [[embezzlement]]. His government is alleged to have embezzled more than [[United States dollar|US$]]1 million.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6403923.stm "Liberia's ex-leader 'stole $1m'"], ''[[BBC News Online]]'', 28 February 2007.</ref> On 12 March a warrant was issued for his arrest. He was not immediately arrested because he was said to be absent from [[Monrovia]] and in [[Lofa County]] instead,<ref>[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?sf=86&set_id=1&click_id=86&art_id=nw20070313123746707C920485 "Liberia to arrest ex-interim president"], [[Agence France Press|AFP]] (''Independent Online''), 13 March 2007.</ref> but on 13 March he was arrested and released on bond shortly thereafter.<ref>Naomi Schwarz, [http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2007-03/2007-03-13-voa51.cfm "Former Liberian Transitional President Arrested for Corruption"], ''[[Voice of America]] News'', 13 March 2007.</ref> In court on 25 April, the defense argued that Bryant constitutionally enjoyed immunity for actions taken as head of state, while the prosecution argued that he did not because his appointment resulted from the Accra Accords in August 2003 and occurred outside the constitutional framework.<ref>[http://www.jeuneafrique.com/fluxafp/fil_info.asp?reg_id=0&art_cle=36468 "Liberia: le parquet général dénie toute immunité à l'ex-président Bryant"], [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] (''[[Jeune Afrique|Jeuneafrique.com]]''), 25 April 2007 {{fr icon}}.</ref> On 24 August 2007, the Supreme Court ruled in favor of the prosecution's argument, enabling Bryant's trial to continue.<ref>[http://www.jeuneafrique.com/fluxafp/fil_info.asp?art_cle=38841 "Liberia: la Cour suprême donne son feu vert pour juger l'ex-président Bryant"], [[Agence France Press|AFP]] (''[[Jeune Afrique|Jeuneafrique.com]]''), 24 August 2007 {{fr icon}}.</ref>
Bryant was arrested on 7 December 2007<ref name=Arrested>Nico Colombant, [http://www.voanews.com/english/2007-12-07-voa26.cfm "Liberia's Former Leader Bryant Is Arrested in Corruption Probe"], VOA News, December 7, 2007.</ref><ref name=Ex>[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/71BC58B1-581A-461F-99FE-047EA455894B.htm "Ex-Liberia president arrested"], Al Jazeera, December 7, 2007.</ref> after failing to appear in court earlier in the week.<ref name=Arrested/><ref name=Held>[http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_2234877,00.html "Liberia's ex-president held"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430122235/http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_2234877,00.html |date=2008-04-30 }}, News24.com, December 7, 2007.</ref> He had said that he was boycotting the court because of his belief that he enjoys immunity.<ref name=Held/> As he was being taken to a prison in Monrovia, he said: "This is a very, very dark day for Liberia. This is the reward we get for restoring peace and democracy to our country."<ref name=Ex/> He was released from the central prison in Monrovia on 8 December after he signed a commitment to appear in court on 10 December.<ref>[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/12/08/africa/AF-GEN-Liberia-Ex-President.php "Ex-Liberian president released from jail"], Associated Press (''International Herald Tribune''), December 8, 2007.</ref>
On 30 April 2009, Bryant, along with four others, was acquitted of embezzling US$1 million from the state oil refinery.<ref>[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=86&art_id=nw20090501151133549C215305 "Ex-Liberian president acquitted of theft"], Sapa-Associated Press (''IOL''), 1 May 2009.</ref> Additional charges regarding the alleged theft of US$1.3 million from the state were dropped on 24 September 2010 as the government failed to provide any proof of wrongdoing.<ref>[http://www.frontpageafrica.com/newsmanager/anmviewer.asp?a=11530&z=37 "Reconciliatory Gesture Or Political Compromise? Why NTGL’s Bryant Walked. "], FrontPageAfrica, 24 September 2010.</ref>
==Personal== Born in Monrovia during the early years of the [[William Tubman|Tubman era]], Bryant's mother was a descendant of settlers and his father was a member of the [[Grebo people]]. He matriculated at [[Cuttington University]] in 1972, and in 1974 he married the former Rosilee Williams; together they had two children, Cheryl and Charles. Bryant also had a son named Charles Mleh. Before becoming the chairman of the interim government, he was a successful businessman operating a company that supplied machinery for the [[Freeport of Monrovia]], and he was the chairman of the [[Liberian Action Party]],<ref>Weiner, Tim. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/08/22/international/africa/22BRYA.html A Man Without Enemies: Charles Gyude Bryant]". ''[[The New York Times]]'' 2003-08-22. Accessed 2013-01-26.</ref> which has since merged with President Sirleaf's [[Unity Party (Liberia)|Unity Party]].<ref>Fahngon, Jimmey C. "[http://www.theliberianjournal.com/index.php?st=news&sbst=details&rid=974&comesOfTheHome=1 UP, LAP, LUP Merged: Ellen Says It's A Dream Come True]". ''Liberian Journal'' 2009-04-02. Accessed 2013-01-26.</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Harold Pupkewitz | image = | caption = | imagesize = | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1915|7|14}} | birth_place = [[Vilno]], Russian Empire (now Lithuania) | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2012|4|27|1915|7|14}} | death_place = [[Windhoek]], Namibia | spouse = Ethel née Meyerovitz | children = 2 | years_active = 1937–2012 | occupation = Entrepreneur }}
'''Harold Pupkewitz''' (14 July 1915 – 27 April 2012) was a Namibian entrepreneur and member of the President's Economic Advisory Council. He was the Executive Chairman of Pupkewitz Holdings, a group of builders' merchants, car sale businesses, and a host of other enterprises, from its foundation in 1946 until his death. Pupkewitz directed the boards of several important Namibian companies, among them [[NamPost]], [[NamPower]], [[Telecom Namibia]], and [[MTC Namibia]], and served as president of a number of high-profile political and economical institutions.
==Early life and education== Harold Pupkewitz was born in [[Vilno]] Russian Empire, on 14 July 1915. He moved to [[South West Africa]] in 1925 together with his mother Anna and his two brothers, Morris and Julius. After completing secondary school at [[Windhoek High School]] in 1932 he went to [[Cape Town]] for further studies. He graduated from [[University of Cape Town]] in 1935 with a [[Bachelor of Commerce]] and stayed to work in Cape Town for two more years. While on a holiday in [[Windhoek]] in 1937 he decided to join the management of the family business, which at that time had developed from an [[ox wagon]] manufacturing enterprise to that of a [[general dealer]], selling household wares and groceries.<ref name="Eco90">{{cite news |url = http://www.economist.com.na/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=17659 |title = Business icon celebrates 90 years |date = 15 July 2005 |newspaper = [[Namibia Economist]] |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110928034124/http://www.economist.com.na/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=17659 |archivedate = 28 September 2011 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Pupkewitz has thus managed the Pupkewitz group of companies for 75 years, from 1937 to 2012.<ref name="NID">{{cite web |url = http://www.nid.org.na/view_book_entry.php?book_id=146 |title = Who's who, entry for Harold Pupkewitz |publisher = Namibia Institute for Democracy |accessdate = 8 April 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110611175130/http://www.nid.org.na/view_book_entry.php?book_id=146 |archivedate = 11 June 2011 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
==Development of the family business== The Pupkewitz family business was founded by Harold's father Max in 1902 as an ox wagon building and repair enterprise. In 1904 at the onset of the [[Herero Wars|Herero and Namaqua War]] he opened shop in [[Okahandja]], strategically situated between [[Windhoek]] and the coastal towns of [[Walvis Bay]] and [[Swakopmund]]. Max Pupkewitz travelled to Europe in 1912, was jailed for his support of the German colonialists, and only returned in 1920. At that time, railways had been constructed and the era of ox wagon transportation in South West Africa was over. Max Pupkewitz opened a general dealer business in Windhoek in 1925, the year the rest of the family resettled here.<ref name="Eco90"/>
In July 1946, Harold Pupkewitz co-founded ''M Pupkewitz and Sons''. The portfolio at first mainly consisted of building material and farm supplies but was expanded in 1954 with the addition of a furniture shop and a motor car sale business.<ref name="Eco90"/>
When [[Volvo]] suspended their engagement in Southern Africa because of concerns about the [[apartheid]] system, Pupkewitz bought the local [[Toyota]] business in 1975.<ref name="Eco90"/> Later [[Hino Motors|Hino]] trucks and the [[Nissan Motors|Nissan]] franchise were added. In 2002 the car sales branch had grown to be the largest in Namibia. Apart from Windhoek, the Pupkewitz group has outlets in many other places in Namibia, among them Walvis Bay, [[Keetmanshoop]], [[Grootfontein]], [[Otjiwarongo]], [[Gobabis]], and [[Aranos]]. In 1981, ''Pupkewitz Holdings'' was founded as umbrella organisation for the different companies.<ref name="Rep87">{{cite news |url=http://www.republikein.com.na/politiek-en-nasionale/harold-pupkewitz-grootste-onder-die-grotes.37857.php |title=Harold Pupkewitz, grootste onder die grotes |trans-title=Harold Pupkewitz, biggest among the big |language=Afrikaans |last=Schlechter |first=Deon |date=1 August 2002 |newspaper=[[Die Republikein]]}}</ref> In 2005 this group of companies, which is a well-known brand in Namibia, employed 848 people nationally.<ref name="NID"/>
==Service in other institutions== Pupkewitz served on the boards of different companies and organisations for much of his life. Before [[Namibian War of Independence|Namibian independence]] he was member of the Foreign Exchange Liaison Committee (1948–1954), the Administrator-General's Advisory Council (1979–1990), president of the Chamber of Commerce and Industries of South West Africa (1981/82), the Institute of Economic Affairs of South West Africa, the South African Institute of International Affairs (1982–1990), and director of Namib Air and Namib Airlines (the predecessor of [[Air Namibia]]).<ref name="Rep87"/><ref name=AZ94>{{cite news |url=http://www.az.com.na/lokales/harold-pupkewitz-wird-94.88797.php |title=Harold Pupkewitz wird 94. Vorbild-Unternehmer feiert heute Geburtstag |trans-title=Harold Pupkewitz becomes 94. Exceptional entrepreneur celebrates birthday today |language=German |date=14 July 2009 |newspaper=[[Allgemeine Zeitung (Namibia)|Allgemeine Zeitung]]}}</ref>
In Namibia he served as director on the boards of [[NamPost]] (1992–2000), [[City Savings and Investment Bank]] (1994–2002), [[MTC Namibia]] (1996–2000), [[Telecom Namibia]] (1992–2007), chairman of [[NamPower]] (1996–2000), and president of the [[Namibia Employers' Federation]] (1998–2007). He was a member of the President's Economic Advisory Council since 1997.<ref name="NID"/><ref name="Rep87"/><ref name=AZ94/>
==Awards and recognition== Pupkewitz was one of the leading entrepreneurs of Namibia.<ref name=EcoHF>{{cite news |url=http://www.economist.com.na/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12768 |title=First Business Hall of Fame |date=23 April 2004 |work=[[Namibia Economist]]}}</ref> He received a number of awards for his contributions towards the country's business development: * 2001: Professional Management Review’s (PMR) Diamond Arrow Award<ref name="NID"/> * 2003: PMR Business Achiever of the Year for Namibia<ref name="NID"/> * 2004: Laureate of the Namibian Business Hall of Fame<ref name=EcoHF/>
[[Polytechnic of Namibia]] named its postgraduate branch of business management ''Harold Pupkewitz Graduate School of Business'' after Pupkewitz made a 10 million [[Namibian dollar|N$]] donation towards the School's development. In 2011 the institution awarded him a Doctorate ''[[honoris causa]]'' in Business Management for his contribution towards business development in Namibia.<ref name="NEDr">{{cite news |url = http://www.newera.com.na/article.php?articleid=38355 |title = Hundreds graduate from Poly |date = 18 April 2011 |work = [[New Era (Namibia)|New Era]] |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120331025657/http://www.newera.com.na/article.php?articleid=38355 |archivedate = 31 March 2012 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
==Family and private life== Harold Pupkewitz married Ethel née Meyerovitz in 1952. They had two children.<ref name="Eco90"/> He was a workaholic until advanced age.<ref name="NID"/> In 2011, at the age of 95, he still worked full-time six days a week as Executive Chairman of ''Pupkewitz Holdings''.<ref name="AZ90">{{cite news |url=http://www.az.com.na/wirtschaft/geschftsmann-auf-lebenszeit-harold-pupkewitz-wird-90.11862.php |title=Geschäftsmann auf Lebenszeit: Harold Pupkewitz wird 90 |trans-title=Life-time businessman: Harold Pupkewitz becomes 90 |language=German |date=14 July 2005 |newspaper=[[Allgemeine Zeitung (Namibia)|Allgemeine Zeitung]]}}</ref>
Apart from his activities in the family business, Pupkewitz was farming on farm ''Us'' on the banks of [[Kuiseb River]] from 1946 to 1985. He was an active rugby player, horse rider, and horse trainer between 1942 and 1962 and has won several trophies.<ref name="Rep87"/>
Pupkewitz was a member of Windhoek's small [[Jews in Namibia|Jewish]] community, the ''Windhoek Hebrew Congregation'', and has attended its [[shul]] for almost its entire time of existence. He was the congregation's Honorary Vice-President. He also served as Vice-Chairman of the [[African Jewish Congress]] and has actively fought [[antisemitism]] in the past.<ref name="AJC">{{cite web |url=http://www.africanjewishcongress.com/namibia1.htm |title=Small congregation fights valiant fight |date=November 2004 |publisher=African Jewish Congress |accessdate=8 April 2011}}</ref>
Pupkewitz died in Windhoek on 27 April 2012 from a heart attack.<ref>{{cite news |title = Funeral Arrangements – Harold Pupkewitz |url = http://www.inamibia.co.na/news/local/item/15952-funeral-arrangements-harold-pupkewitz.html |last = Mietzner |first = Peter |date = 28 April 2012 |work = inamibia |publisher = umuntu media |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120708055309/http://www.inamibia.co.na/news/local/item/15952-funeral-arrangements-harold-pupkewitz.html |archivedate = 8 July 2012 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
